The real issue here is that the repo "typesafe.artifactoryonline.com" doesn't contain a valid "sbt-launch.jar".

And, the second repo "repo.typesafe.com", does have a valid "sbt-launch.jar", but then it requires wget/curl to follow redirects.

This exactly what this patch fixes.

What are you basing the doc change on?

Experience and other user feedback I found online. When trying to deploy it rolls back and logs this error: "Value (us-east-1a) for parameter availabilityZone is invalid. Subnets can currently only be created in the following availability zones: us-west-2b, us-west-2a, us-west-2c". Just updating the documentation to reflect the availabilityzones that are supported.

This compiles, but I get Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/joda/time/base/BaseInterval at runtime. 
replacing the ShadeRule with this one:

ShadeRule.rename("org.joda.time.base.**" -> "shadeio.@1").inLibrary("org.elasticsearch" % "elasticsearch"  % elasticsearchVersion.value).inProject

resolves it. Please make that change, thanks.
@EmergentOrder thanks for the fix.

testing indicates a silent failure during training, which is probably because the write to ES using Spark requires an upgrade of the ES-Hadoop lib, from the docs: "ES-Hadoop 2.2.x and higher are compatible with Elasticsearch 1.X and 2.X" See discussion here: https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-hadoop

Looks like you can try 2.2.0-rc1https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch-hadoop#beta-release-currently-220-rc1
I didn't think ES-Hadoop was a dependency in PIO. Not seeing it required anywhere...
ES-Hadoop is not a dependency of PIO proper, but rather of the Universal Recommendation Template
This change is incorrect, as which availability zones will work varies based on user account & other factors.
I don't see a dependency in the template. Do you mean the server needs ES-Hadoop installed for UR to work with ES 2.x? Why not with ES 1.x?

in the UR build.sbt 

```
"org.elasticsearch" % "elasticsearch-spark_2.10" % "2.1.0.Beta4"
  exclude("org.apache.spark", "spark-catalyst_2.10")
  exclude("org.apache.spark", "spark-sql_2.10"),
```

The upcoming v0.3.0 uses v 2.1.2. This is a packaging of ES-hadoop that includes only the Spark deps. \

We have recently tested it in the version that supports ES 2.x in 2.2-rc2 but using ES 1.7.4. The libs is the first version that is designed to work with ES 2.x as well as 1.x.

Ah, got it. Thanks! I'll test out an updated build shortly.

Hi @jramos . Try this before run sbt test:

$ set -a
$ source conf/pio-env.sh
$ set +a

there are some development notes in README of https://github.com/PredictionIO/PredictionIO/tree/develop/data . it would be great if you could help update it too if you see anything unclear.

Thanks @monckdav !

Hello Hyukjin,

Thanks for contributing. There are two key changes in this PR: 1. Converting a `case class Foo() extends Serializable` into `case class Foo()`.  2. Converting a `class Foo() extends Serializable` into a `case class Foo()`.

Case 1 is good, since it is redundant to mixin `Serializable` into a `case class`.

But we have to be careful with the case 2, since scala forbids case-to-case inheritance, in other words, we cannot have another `case class Bar() extends Foo()`. In these examples, users may want to extends an existing `TrainingData` and create multiple subclass, each serving slightly different purpose. Because of the case-to-case restriction, even if we have base `case class FOO()`, all subclasses still need to be a non-case-class, which defies this PR's purpose of "fixing mixed usage of case class and class with serializable interface."
@yipjustin I see. Thanks! Let me remove those changes.
@yipjustin Thanks for comments. I just removed the changes.
